review_title: Ambitious work with dedicated employees, but poor leadership made for a toxic environment
job_title: Science Curriculum Specialist in Berkeley, CA
pros:
I am a former employee of the Learning Design Group (LDG) in the Lawrence Hall of Science at UC Berkeley, who was working there around the time that it first adopted the name, and worked there for over five years. My own previous work experience includes both science teaching and education research.

There were some decidedly good things about working at LDG. The kind of work it aspires to sits at a rare intersection of practical and principled curriculum design. The group develops curriculum activities and learning sequences that are created, piloted, and revised to be usable by teachers in classrooms, are grounded in design principles that have ties to cognitive and socio-cultural learning theories, and embody the three dimensions of the newly released NGSS. The sequences integrate instruction and assessment around a progression of goals for increasingly complex conceptual understanding and facility with science practice. In partnership with Amplify Science, the LDG has created an initial K-8 science and literacy curriculum program that is being adopted in school districts across the country, and will impact the learning of millions of students. The combination of principled design and broad impact is rare in the world of school curriculum development, which is heavily populated by minimally updated, information-dense textbooks with loosely aligned accompanying activities. 

	The majority of people who came to work at the LDG were committed to improving education, invested in good outcomes for children, and ready to work hard toward worthwhile goals. There were many who were very creative, quick to try out and take up new ideas, and put intense thought and effort into development. It was a real pleasure to work with people who were enthusiastic about their work and about creating a quality product. There are unfortunately few opportunities to learn or practice this kind of ambitious curriculum design, particularly as part of a larger team, so few of us came in specifically prepared for it. Most employees came from teaching, and a smaller number from academia, often making for a significant learning curve. Had it been managed differently, this situation might have been fine.
cons:
The LDG offered an opportunity to work with dedicated people on a product that has the potential to change education in schools, but its leadership and management made the working environment unpleasant, even toxic. While they frequently touted the value of an open, collaborative work environment, the leaders didn’t support the kind of transparency and trust that fosters one. They seemed to cling to the more informal, organic approaches to design and decision-making they had used as a much smaller group in the past. While they encouraged idea-sharing and discussion, they often avoided making even tentative explicit decisions. Despite requests from our team, they were reluctant to try to formally describe curriculum design processes in a way that could have provided a clear focus for training and collaboration in our much larger group. Without having formalized the work of designing curriculum for themselves, they didn’t seem able to define the skills they needed to hire for. They repeatedly hired people who were significantly unprepared for the work, and several times resorted to hiring friends or family members. There were consequently many employees who lacked relevant skills and received only cursory training, but whom leaders nonetheless expected to do the same work as experienced developers. This placed unreasonable demands on new hires, and forced more experienced employees to overextend themselves to try and fill the gaps. In addition, leaders seemed to have allowed previous projects to create a kind of ‘fiefdom’ culture within the group; when I started, members already seemed to fearfully guard parts of the curriculum they saw as belonging to science or literacy, and thought might be somehow taken from them. The lack of clear processes and decisions, poor hiring and training, and entrenched territoriality unsurprisingly often produced confusion and disagreement. Rather than treating emerging tensions as symptoms, and using them as opportunities to reveal and work on underlying issues, leaders typically tried to find a quick superficial solution, or make them go away by reorganizing personnel, and left the fundamental work culture problems intact. In general, leaders seemed to value product over people - as long as work continued, they did not appear overly concerned with the effects on the people who were doing it. 

Coupled with these organizational issues was a lack of transparency and authenticity in leaders’ communication and interaction. Good collaboration requires transparency and collective understanding, and leaders could be opaque or even secretive about decisions that impacted the team, and the factors and reasoning that led to them. This made their motives seem suspect, and made our work seem like less of a collective effort. I also learned not to trust the content or tone of their communications. They presented a smile and a cheerful tone regardless of whether they were ready to praise or penalize, and the constant forced positivity quickly rang false. I found that if I went to them for help with a concern or a problem, I would get an initial show of empathy and understanding that reassured me, but their subsequent response would be dismissive or even punitive. As I found myself held accountable for requests or directives they hadn’t explicitly made, I learned that some leaders expected that I would understand the intent outside the content of what they said, and who would look for implicit meaning in any communication. These patterns as a whole made it hard to believe what was said, or to trust that the goal posts weren’t about to be moved. 

	I should have left the LDG sooner, but ambitious curriculum work is pretty rare, and I stayed well beyond the point it was harmful to me. I believe some things have improved since I left - the curriculum and its development processes have been clarified out of necessity, and most employees have been there for a while and are familiar with the work, but its leaders are the same. I don’t think I can recommend it to anyone who hopes to apply to be part of an open, collaborative curriculum project. But if you are applying as a leader who is confident they can foster one, the work and people are there.

As a public institution in a state with a history of pleasing constituencies, the bureaucracy of U.C. is horribly bloated with cumbersome policies/rules that get in the way. I am fortunate to be well insulated from most of this by excellent departmental staff, but few other departments have it so good.

review_title: Despite low salary, the President's Postdoctoral Fellowship is good vehicle to transition into an academic position
pros: Reputation, first and foremost. The UC President's Postdoctoral Fellowship is one of the most prestigious postdoctoral fellowships in the United States. Your CV may go to a "better pile" when being considered for an academic position in the future. Theoretically, it also facilitates transition to tenured academic positions within the UC system, but lack of actual positions available for application ultimately make no difference for the fellow, who will likely and more easily get a job somewhere else outside the system. A great perk of this postdoctoral fellowship is that teaching is not allowed, leaving an unusual amount of time to advance research and publications. There are not many postdocs of this kind anywhere else. Program support for the fellows is very good (annual workshops, networking, etc.)
cons: LOW salary. $41,200 in 2011, plus 4,000 in research funds (travel to conferences, translation services, educational materials, workshops, etc.). Considering the cost of life in California (especially rent), and the monthly financial weight of student loans (for those who have outstanding debt), the salary is more than tight. In fact, it is <very> tight.

Directors have no clue what their own staff are doing and take no initiative in having productive meetings to find out.  Directors come and go as they please and pretend to be committed to housings mission statement.

review_title: Incredible diversity and brainpower, but choose your adviser well.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros:
The campus has a lot of support for diversity. Regardless of your opinions on politics, religion, or hot button issues, you can probably find a student group in support (or against) the subject. 

The university is full of really really smart people (faculty, grad students, undergrads, etc).
cons: The city of Berkeley tends to breed stubborn, left-wing hippies. This is a generalization, I know. I just want to make the point that the city is only accepting toward those who have the same ideals. It irks me that people who desire to be so open to "free thought and expression" have so little respect for people who have differing opinions.

review_title: Great co-workers,  great location, decent benefits, low pay
pros: A highly educated workforce, at present good benefits (though they are eroding), some opportunities for creativity.  Nice weather, some great lunchtime hike opportunities in the Berkeley hills.  Love the department I work for, often disappointed by the senior management.
cons: A constantly increasing workload, reliance on Peoplesoft programs for data processing, salary is not sufficient to live in the Bay Area and is falling further behind each year.  The University finds ways to give faculty more money, spends no effort finding ways to give staff more money.  The administration wants us to fit into McJobs and move to other departments in order to receive promotions rather than recognizing the value of long-term staff to a department and encouraging people to develop additional skills where they already are.

review_title: Proud to work at UCSF.  Ashamed to work for the University of CA.

review_title: Career employee sees waste at UC Berkeley
pros: Great benefits, flexible work hours, opportunities to take classes
cons: Morale at UC Berkeley is low, and I've seen a lot of unethical behavior over the years. Staff are promoted out of their competence level and "work the system" and sometimes break blatant rules and play favorites. Misconduct goes on and rarely results in someone being fired. Operation Excellent is a good idea, but the great amounts of money being spent to ultimately save money result in "going around the rules." I see it on a daily basis in procurement, hiring, and augmenting senior managers' pockets. I used to be very proud to work at UC Berkeley, but no longer, and would not recommend it to others just starting out.

review_title: Lots of red tape, incompetent middle management and employees, but flexible with good benefits

pros:
-Flexibility in work arrangements, especially for those with families
-Great benefits
-3 weeks of vacation to start, with at least 10 sick days and all national holidays per year
cons:
-Lots and lots and lots of red tape
-Too much power given to academia at UC locations (bending over backwards to unreasonable levels to accommodate professors, further cultivating their counterproductive sense of entitlement)
-Many incompetent middle managers and employees, who are "promoted to their level of incompetence" instead of being let go.  (It's almost impossible to be fired at UC, and people take advantage of this.)
-Departments here are huge fans of pointless (and expensive) meetings that waste time and force some employees to stay late to make up for missed work time
-Not much room for career growth.  Many have been in the same position for decades.
-Low pay, relative to market levels.

pros: The University of California offers flexible schedules and time off for vacation and sick days. It is a great work environment. The people are great and really friendly. If you enjoy working with students then the University of California is the place for you. There is a lot of emphasis placed on meeting the needs of the campus community, which includes students, staff, and faculty alike. The UC system is one of the largest and most distinguished public school systems in the nation...you can't beat that!
cons: Working for a public university does not pay a six figure salary. The wages of the administration in comparison to those employees at the bottom of the food chain is sad! Parking sucks and it costs an arm and a leg and despite increasing student fees there always seems to be budget cuts around every corner.

review_title: A lot of variance in position
job_title: Junior Specialist II in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: This quite a diverse title used in the university and can include many different areas of specialized research depending on which lab and department you work in. However, the salary ranges are set by the university and have predictable wage increases. Great benefits and retirement (more about that in the cons)
cons: I'm not sure if this a con, but it is a salary position which means you may work long hours without any overtime pay, but for the most part things even out in the end. If you are in it for the long hall then the retirement plan is good, but if you are younger or planning on working only temporarily the retirement commitment is HUGE and MANDATORY. After taxes and and retirement and everything is taken out I only receive 2/3 of my gross income.

review_title: The UC Can Be a Great Lifetime Employer

cons: Political environments at some UC campuses can sometimes foster poor work conditions and hamper internal upward mobility, Salaries don't tend to match similar titles in the private sector, Some UC campuses employ "sink or swim" tactics with new entry-level employees, Lack of in-person employee development opportunities

job_title: Administrative Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Hard-working nice colleagues. Interesting work sometimes.
cons: Many. Management has a culture of not praising its employees, but rather pointing out the flaws. And the managers that do support their staff, can get trampled on by their bosses. We pay $81per month for parking, yet most of us walk at least 4 blocks to our cars. HR in Health is the worst HR I have ever come across - they do not communicate with you, and will do nothing to help you in your quest for a raise. The only way to get a better pay is to move around the university... or leave.

pros: Great scientific environment, with a lot of top game scientist. The graduate students and postdocs are also of the highest quality. An open and friendly work environment, with a high degree of team spirit and team work. The technical facilities are of high quality. There is a good mix of different nationalities and a willingness to do interdisciplinary work. The variety of research makes it possible to broaden ones scientific horizon.
cons: The universities has a lack of suitable workspace. The buildings are worn down. The credit crisis is working to increase this effect, maybe this will clear up along with the Californian economy.

job_title: Student Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: In short, the logistics crew is a very fun crew to join for students looking for work during the summer and during the school year also. It is full time during the summer so you can earn a few bucks, and during the school year, it is part time, and very flexible so you can have your work schedule tailored to your school schedule
cons: It doesn't offer your any professional skills for academics. Although you can gain general professional experience, you can't really get any profession skills related to your major to help with your career.

pros: The University operates like it's own city with its infrastructure and autonomy from the City of Davis. There is usually good work-life balance and training opportunities through Staff Development to further build your career. The medical benefits are great.
cons: Not all departments allow staffing to participate in the Staff Development courses or treat staffing the same for work-life balance. Although the campus is large, everyone knows everyone and reputation can prevent a person from moving forward.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Berkeley, CA

cons: Salary as GSI alone will not cover cost of living in the Bay Area. Many of us had other jobs on the side, as research assistants or off campus.

pros: The UC is well known for cutting edge research and great faculty. As a postdoc, it provides a perfect environment to build your career. I'm not sure about other postdocs' situations, but I get a full medical/dental/vision health insurance plan and 4 weeks of paid vacation.
cons: There can be a lot of big egos to wade through at times, but if you work for the right people there is no reason you can't succeed.

pros: Plenty of people have good experiences working at UC Berkeley. Usually it's because they are fortunate enough to have colleagues and supervisors who care more than they have to.
cons: On an institutional level, there is very little quality control. Dysfunctionality is the default state of things.  Lots of red tape.

job_title: Middle Office Accountant (Analyst) in Oakland, CA
pros: Exciting job managing the fixed income trading team.  Management appreciates ideas, and ways to solve problems, and they listen and comment.  Salary is very nice, could be better based on what I have brought to the table, which is a lot.
cons: My particular department is not part of the bonus pool.  We are considered a group that has nothing to do with the investment process and are therefore ineligible for additional compensation, even if the annual performance appraisal is stellar....mine was.

pros: Some of the best reasons to work for the University of California include flexible schedule, which is mandatory for all students.  Additionally, you may have an opportunity to work closely with a professor, or graduate students, and earn one or many credible letters of recommendation.  Future employers know that student jobs at a University are often highly sought after, and your resume will benefit greatly if you are able to show good performance in your job.
cons: Many jobs are only available to students, which can make life difficult around graduation, if you have not secured another job that begins right away.

review_title: A once good place to work that has been overtaken by overpaid, terrible executive and senior management.
pros: Some people on the frontline doing actual work.  Less and less of these numbers as new hires are pretty disappointing more often than not.
cons: Terrible communication in that misleading (at the minimum and outright lies in some cases)  communication is constantly spewed.  Way too top heavy.  While underlings are told to make due with less, top management is over-compensated with the famliiar refrain that we need to pay more to get and retain the best.

pros: As a teacher you can be proud to work for the best public university in the U.S.
cons: The students are a mixed lot.  California secondary schooling has steadily declined over the last thirty years.  At the same time, the UC system lowered its standards to boost enrollment numbers. You meet and teach some wonderfully talented students, but both faculty and students are weighed down by the 30-35% of pupils who are not prepared for university study.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Most everything is run by students, meaning everyone is fully cognizant of the responsibilities of working while being in school. You have full say in how many hours you want to work per week, and picking up extra shifts (and extra money) is pretty painless. Friendly work environment. Easy to move up.
cons: Just as easily as it is to pick shifts up, it can be difficult to find covers day-of (in the event of you waking up and needing a sick day, for example). Also, while you can request a max number of hours, you don't always get that many. Hours vary. You have to stand for long periods of time.

review_title: Typical Government Job - Lots of Waste!
job_title: Technical Staff in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good benefits. Managers come and go as they please.  2-hour lunches, shopping, etc. Excellent technical staff - very knowledgeable.
cons: Wasteful - spending too much of tax payers money on travel/conferences - boondoggle - why send multiple managers to same conference except to party!!! Multiple layers of management, too many incompetent managers, inefficient, bureaucracy at its best.  Have to brown nose around here to get raises. No pay raise for several years.

review_title: No good for young motivated poeple, good for those who wants stability and great benefits.
pros: Retirement benefits, general health benefits. 8-5 work hours. many holidays. starts with 3 weeks (12 days after xmas holiday) paid vacation. Can be low pressure low profile...very "safe" place. Job security. Or if you are veteran of industry, this may be a good place to slow down.
cons: Below market pay, lack of growth professionally and personally. Your unit that you work in will determine your growth potential. Work at a school with little funding, you will be very limited. Work for a Campus wide organization you will be better off. It is very difficult for staff to shine here, because faculty and academic needs generally trump professional staff. Such as in budge cut years. Pay usually starts at the bottom of the grade and is not negotiable. There are generally no bonuses, sometimes you may win awards which may give you serveral hundred dollars. Your best performance does not lead to pay increase, each year is at 3% and in budget cut years, there maybe no raise at all.

pros: Job is not stressful.  Easy to leave work at work.  Benefits are very good.
cons: UC is the definition of bureaucracy.  Promotions are made based on who you know or who you want to influence, not merit.  Salary increases are tied to inflation, although the cost of benefits is increasing faster, resulting in a net decrease.  Annual reviews are a joke and are not tied to metrics, goals, or salary increases.

review_title: data science research on computer science and medicine
pros: got to work with top researchers in computer science and data mining, public health and medicine, and engineering. strong work ethic to have an impact on helping society. i worked with wei and sean and got to work with other faculty and students at ucla, uci, ucr, and ucsd. i would recommend to others who are serious about data science in medicine.
cons: if you're main interest in data science is to make a lot of money go to facebook or another place as this place can't compete on money but you can work on things with societal impact

pros: Great Work life balance, and okay compensation. Word Class institution, and great colleagues. Great area to live and work in. Would probably do it again, to be honest.
cons: Academia is arduous and cut throat, I would not recommend staying for any longer than is necessary to find a more lucrative position. Life is short-live it!

review_title: Good place to work, but maybe not for life
job_title: Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You're constantly around students and professionals that have education as a priority - people tend to have more interesting conversations and so work passes more quickly when you're doing a monotonous task.  The work was fairly enjoyable and you're given a lot of freedom with a clear bureaucracy (though there is an obvious hierarchy to get things done through and it's not exactly expedient).
cons:
Still a large "company" with lots of regulations
Pay is alright but by no means exemplary

review_title: Great place, great benefits, dysfunctional bureaucracy
pros: It's a beautiful place, there are some amazing people, the benefits are good and if you work hard you stand out.
cons: Restructuring often without learning much from previous experience, you can get stuck with some awful managers or co-workers.

review_title: riding on its reputation as an institution but not living up to its hype
pros: It's a shame glassdoor is in beta - I wrote a long review that seems to have been lost after I was prompted to Register to be able to post it. This review will be much shorter. The health benefits at UC are, I'm told, pretty good compared to comparable institutions. Pension benefits seem OK,. You have assess to a lot of interesting events by your proximity to campus, though you may not have energy to attend after work.
cons: There are very extensive employee protections and positive career development programs on paper, but it's rare in my experience for Berkeley to actually adhere to them when there is a issue or you think you're ready to be promoted to the next step. The culture generally discourages speaking out when you see things going wrong, even if its high level execs behaving unethically and abusing their position. Financial abuses seem rife. I've worked here at a variety of positions for 20 years and see some truly egregious wastes of taxpayer money. Some I've reported, some I was prevented from doing o, and never have I felt like the reports changed much on either the bog or little picture. Working here, in general, you'll be asked to give a lot and compensated very little, in either money or other acknowledgements.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Overall a good place to work. Some flexibility in schedule allowing opportunity for the unexpected things that come your way from time to time. Management were professional and there when needed. Learned a lot in my time there and was supported by staff around me. Job could be a little stressful at times however i learned a lot while here
cons: Salary was not great for the amount of work and responsibility involved. What I learned and the experience I got was perfect for the next job I got which did have the salary to match.

pros: Working with undergraduate students is very rewarding. The library is undergoing fundamental organizational changes that are overdue. My colleagues are very creative and committed.
cons: Our pension plan is underfunded and the University has failed to take effective action to address the funding issue. We are subject to salary reductions through furlough this year because of the state budget crisis. Librarian salaries lag other California academic libraries by about 15%

job_title: Graduate Student in San Diego, CA
pros: Very technical and comprehensive Structural Engineering graduate program, delves deep into the theory behind advanced structural analysis and current concrete and steel structure design philosophy. Provides in depth background about current state of building codes, and lessons learned towards development of code over the past few decades.
cons: Very demanding and time consuming, was forced to take four classes one quarter which became a struggle to say the least. Get ahead as much as possible, stay on top of all current tasks, and you will find this experience to be both rewarding and valuable for future endeavors.

review_title: Salaries aren't high, benefits are great, people are wonderful, but it's a big institution.
job_title: Systems Analyst IV in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Benefits are great, relaxed work atmosphere, people are wonderful, students are fun, it's in Santa Cruz.
cons: Salaries are low, it's a big institution so things go slow and people can be a bit weird (after you pass probation no one gets fired).

job_title: Doctoral Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: It's a top-notch research institution with beautiful weather, and San Diego is a great town if you love beaches and beer.
cons:
San Diego is wicked expensive
Graduate students are miserable (everywhere). Everyone in your lab will lie when you visit. Get them drunk and find out the truth
Job opportunities are pretty weak in academia in general, but UCSD is particular has a terrible career office compared to Harvard, Yale, Brown, NYU, Stanford, probably Berkeley.
Research institutions are about fame & grant-getters, not your petty career

review_title: Pay too low for the area's living cost
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Irvine, CA
pros: I was a Visiting Assistant Professor at UCI. The position certainly leaves you with a lot of free time (you teach 5 courses a year) for research, family, friends etc.
cons:
No 401k contributions from the school.
Low pay; certainly very low for living in Irvine.
Not very good healthcare (there are good healthcare plans but they are very expensive); school does not provide dental/vision plans. You have to find these plans yourself.
The whole time it feels like postdocs were being treated like dirt.

pros: People are nice overall.  Easy to leave work at work.  Not too stressful.
cons: Typical state bureaucracy.  Lots of rules and regulations, most of which are ignored.  Duplicate work done at UCOP that is also done at each university.  Can be very frustrating, especially if you have a strong work ethic.

job_title: Clinical Assistant/Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Able to experience the hospital environment while working towards finishing Prereqs for the MCAT
-Able to understand and immerse yourself in a clinic with nurses, CNA's, and Physicians.
-Be able to get first hand experience with patients
cons:
-Strange hours
-Not flexible in terms of missing shifts, even though you are volunteering your time
-Parking is a pain

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Like most graduate student researchers, at UCLA you enjoy a more flexible work schedule, winter break, plus (usually) a short summer vacation. Nice campus to walk around, and it is easy to get in touch with administration.
cons: The salary is very low for the city being pretty costly; rent is a little overwhelming if you don't want to spend an hour commuting. Other cons from the general academia field are applicable. The health insurance coverage mostly consists of the student health clinic being free; dental and vision coverage are not great.

job_title: Assistant Director in La Jolla, CA
pros: I had some incredible colleagues who really were there for the students.  They made going into work every day a pleasure.  There are of course some people you do not get along with as well, but there are many opportunities for professional development and growth.
cons: The current state of the budget crisis in California made for not many pay increases and lots of furlow time during holidays.

review_title: Good, flexible place to work as an undergraduate and gain precious research experience.
job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Gain hands on research experience
Very flexible
Great and knowledgeable peers
Good appreciation for work you do
An environment that encourages learning
cons:
Can get repetitive
Might have to work on something no one else wants to work on
May have to spend an unbalanced amount of time on some days

pros: As a tutor, you have the opportunity to make a meaningful impact on your fellow students in the pursuit of their degrees. You gain presentation and leadership skills, confidence in talking in front of large groups, and a nice buck.
cons: There really isn't anything to complain about. Only that if you teach groups, you're options for private tutoring are heavily restricted.

pros: The school provide a great experience in learning business and have practical fieldwork requirement for MBA students. If interested in working distribution center, they have many located in this area.
cons: The expense is a bit high and the location is not close to the job markets, the local business companies are lack of competition and are not actively willing to hire international students.

review_title: Don't be a student employee (or RA).
pros: Work-study. Free room and board. Learning to cope with terrible situations daily.
cons: Overworked, underpaid. As an RA for Berkeley (and a CS student) I have had minimal time to work on side projects. There is no pay, and I don't have time on top of this to get another job for expendable income. When the RAs tried to protest against management their response was to threaten to fire all of us. They treat the RAs as easily replaceable. It's not a good environment.

pros: Great experience working with other State Agencies at the Secretary and Deputy Secretary levels along with members of the Legislature on budgets and audits.
cons: In this position, the Director worked for two bosses and often became leveraged to show each others power.  This resulted in an state agency filing suit to prove command and control.  In the end, the people of California lost.

pros: Name recognition, active postdoc communities, and teaching experience all formed the core pros for my stay at Berkeley
cons: Unfortunately, the department I was in had no postdoc support; they were unprepared to even keep me on list serves or list me on their website even when I was lecturing. The Berkeley pay brackets are some of the narrowest I've encountered and for such an expensive area, formed a real problem. I had essentially no mentoring and found the administrative structure heavy handed and confining.

review_title: Research Assistant for the Social Sciences Division
job_title: Research Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I'm sure this depend on the principal investigator in charge of the project, but I experienced great mentoring and opportunity to learn.
cons: There was no downside to this position. I had flexible hours, off-site work as needed etc

review_title: Excellent university, but value is decreasing.
job_title: Research Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I had excellent opportunities as a research assistant. The facilities were reasonable and the faculty did their jobs. Beautiful campus. I was very pleased with family student housing for my wife and I.
cons: Tuitions continues to increase sharply without providing any additional value. There are some resource constraints and TAs / faculty don't have enough time for individualized attention of undergrads due to large class sizes.

pros: Decent pay for an undergraduate, better than minimum wage working an unrelated service or work-study job.
cons: Research experience varies greatly between disciplines, departments, and research groups.

pros: Good training, friendly atmosphere, organization tries to do the right thing
cons: Financial challenges, cost cutting, impersonal when things are not going well

pros: A lot of career development opportunities via the UCSF Occupational and Professional Career Development Office. There are a lot of seminars through out the various campuses and activities for postdocs. There is a postdoc Union.
cons: Postdocs are in a limbo in HR and no one ever knows how to handle our applications, paper-work, maternity leave, etc. There is no required documentation for PIs to provide career advice or log progress.

job_title: Human Resources Analyst in Merced, CA
pros: The University as a system has great benefits!  Enjoyed working with departments at the University of California Office of the President and employees at UC Merced.
cons: Equity issues.  Politics is stifling at the UC Merced campus.  Management's engagement with employees is very selective.   High level campus management conducts Town Halls in an effort to claim transparency but they are not transparent.    Very disappointing, especially to long-term employees.

review_title: Being the workhorse of UC Berkeley's undergraduate education
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros:
Have a guaranteed income during graduate studies.
Get to meet talented and exceptional individuals.
cons:
More than 50% of the income goes to rent.
Most students are unmotivated and underprepared for the courses.
Sometimes university instructors are not organized and lousy, leaves almost all the work to be done by the graduate student instructors.

review_title: University of California from a students perspective.
pros: The University is within walking distance of my residence. They have better wages compared to companies where my parents work and their hours are really flexible since there are so many people employed.
cons: The pay is low for students and the bureaucracy is difficult to deal with when things need to get done.

review_title: Working in a diverse professional collegiate environment I learned a lot and liked the well rounded atmosphere.
job_title: Human Resources/Payroll Coordinator in Irvine, CA
pros: Working directly with the HR Analyst, gaining higher education knowledge, interacting with the student.
cons: Need major software updates to stay current and efficient with processing things in a timely manner and reduce a lot of unnecessary steps to achieve the same goal

pros: Decent pay and good benefits.
cons: It used to be a nice place to work years ago but I'm afraid that's changed and it's now become a political cesspool.  There are managers to manage the managers and assistants to assist the assistants.  It's just ridiculous.  No promotions.  No raises in pay.  Snobby people to work with.  Just go look for a job elsewhere and don't watse your time.  Administration is incompetent and wasteful.  Staff is not treated well.  Layoffs abound.

pros: Work with fellow students in a fast-paced environment. Learn time managing skills. Everyone gets along and works together very well.
cons: At big events it can be stressful. Sometimes understaffed when catering. Boss expects you to be perfect when no one can. Always on your feet. Only on breaks can you sit down.

job_title: Associate Director, Marketing in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Depending on your supervisor, there is much flexibility to grow into areas of interest; decent pay, great people, fun employee benefits like free game tickets and staff appreciation events, excellent benefits but should include some sort of paid-family leave, very surprised that they don't.
cons: bureaucratic, pay could be better, people in the non-profit world can be very possessive about their projects and their "expertise"

review_title: It is a great place to work and the people are good to work with.
pros: It is a challenging and innovative work environmentm with lots of career choices.
cons: Requires a DOE security to start work, which takes a long time. You get paid while waiting but it can be boring.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in UCLA, CA
pros: I have enjoyed the challenging work, and opportunity for limited growth within my position. I have also been able to interface with schools, administration, etc.
cons: You work much more than your 20 hours per week usually, and get paid a very low salary. I have also been micro-managed by many professors which has been difficult.

pros: They give really good benefits!
cons: They don't have any oversight to make sure academics are not forcing their employees to work overtime. I worked 70+ hours per week for years with no overtime pay, and  was even forced to work 7 days a week for a couple months off the books. It was all illegal, but no one seemed to care.

review_title: The Chemistry Department Was a Great Place to Work
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Chicago, IL
pros: The campus is beautiful and the staff is friendly. Really, with the amazing weather and intellectual atmosphere, the place is kind of a paradise.
cons: As a graduate student or a teaching assistant, you will be working long hours for low pay and very little thanks.

pros: Collegial environment.  UC is great at being at the forefront of dealing with issues and training students for the real world. Campus culture inspires lifelong learning.
cons: As a public institution, it is relying less and less on the State of CA and more on private donations. Therefore more emphasis on fundraising.

job_title: Grant Writer and Analyst in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: The academics at this university are top notch and that is reflected in the quality of the graduates, many of whom choose to work at UCSB.
cons: It is in a relatively remote part of the SB/Goleta region, with few  core 'main street' amenities and community spots to drop in on over your lunch hour.

review_title: University of California Graduate Research Assistant
pros: Academic freedom is excellent. There's a lot of opportunity to find something that your interested in.
cons: It's a very big organization and it's easy to get lost. You can find a lot of different types of people there and if you are looking for something in particular it is probably there.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Irvine, CA
pros: Can be fairly easy as times.  With the right instructor and class, the work can be enjoyable and rewarding.
cons: Preferences and assignments are at the discretion of people in management without any direct experience.  Working for incompetent lecturers can make you lose your mind.

job_title: Doctoral Graduate Student Researcher in La Jolla, CA
pros: Fantastic quality of faculty and resources to learn and perform high level science. There are so many investigators doing so many different things that you can certainly find someone to help you no matter where your research takes you.
cons: The bureaucracy‎ of the university can be tedious sometimes.  Also budget cutting makes it more and more difficult to function as a student.

pros: Benefits are ok.  Retirement pension is great to have.  Somewhat of job security.  Flexible hours is great help for single parents.
cons: ZERO appreciation for dedicated employees that stay with the company long term.  They push their older/higher paying employees out the door the first chance they get.

job_title: Mid Level Management in Oakland, CA
pros: The teaching and research missions are inspiring. No pressure to work long hours. Right next to BART.
cons: Salary is below industry rate. Good performance and bad performance are treated the same. Little opportunity for advancement, as people stay longer than they should to get the retirement benefit. External candidates get preference when a job does open up.

job_title: Student Affairs Coordinator in Berkeley, CA
pros: Cal offers departments with great team dynamics and brilliant students all situated on a beautiful campus.  The health benefits are amazing.
cons: Cal has an antiquated hiring system and primarily promotes from within.  There's so much bureaucracy and paperwork that completing certain tasks can be challenging.  Employees would benefit from periodic training to leverage their skills.

review_title: Stimulating environment; too much red tape
job_title: Program Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great working environment on a university campus, collaborative work with other departments, lot of opporunities for professional development and movement within the campus system, great benefits
cons: Working at a public university also comes with a lot of red tape and useless restrictions on salaries and hiring. The pace of administrative changes is extremely slow and cautious.

pros: Benefits are amazing. Access to unlimited training and certifications using Lynda.com
cons: Internal politics are a mess. Policies and procedures need updating. Ratio of faculty and students to support staff is absolutely ridiculous.

review_title: IT Support Assistant at UC San Diego
job_title: IT Support Assistant in La Jolla, CA
pros: Amazing staff, flexible hours and decent pay for a part time job. Can be in the job despite beingn international student
cons: Payroll sometimes is not processed on time, there is a lot of other workers with which communication is hard

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: cutting-edge science carried out by outstanding faculty, easy access to resources for research
cons: no discernible campus culture, isolating working conditions (varying by lab, of course),  Mission Bay campus is state-of-the-art, but desolate and depressing

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: Cozy atmosphere from the smallness of the sizes of different campuses, world class scientists and facilities and perks of being in San Francisco
cons: Very few departments and not enough emphasis on the physical sciences. A sense of life outside the building hardly exists from a consequence of cold winds and a mostly 9-5 culture

pros: Large organization experience, coupled with PhD, and Nobel Laureate environment.
cons: Intern review based upon 3 months experience.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: Once you realize you can't really get anything done there, you can take advantage of the fact that it is basically a consequence-free environment, and spend your time training for your next job.
cons: Too much drama on every level, no accountability for bad and ridiculous unprofessional behavior,  too difficult to get anything done, several incompetent people who are catered to. I was once told to me face, "do not take initiative." That pretty much says it all.

review_title: University committed to diversity and experiential learning
job_title: Orientation Leader in La Jolla, CA
pros: Community, camaraderie, work life balance
cons: Poor and expensive parking, campus politics

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Unique collaboration opportunities help you learn more and accomplish  publications  in higher impact journals
cons: Postdoctoral Salary is a joke. For international postdocs UC does not offer a green card sponsorship so overall chances for applying for federal grants decrease a lot and thus the growth tends to be limited.

review_title: good place to work..but be prepared to work hard and with not much support.
pros: benefits, co-workers are great. good career opportunities if you know how to work the system.
cons:
Must be a self starter, otherwise you won't make it here.
low salary compared to private sector

job_title: Associate Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very talented and dedicated staff. Excellent exposure to a full range of issues facing higher education institutions. Most positions involve interacting with the campuses within the system.
cons: Bureaucratic at times, but not more than is to be expected with an organization of this size.

job_title: Numerous Student Jobs in Oakland, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule that balanced the student curriculum with gaining useful experience for the working world (graduation).
cons: Pay is next to abysmal. Very difficult offset the costs of attending a UC in this day and age.

job_title: Learning Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: It is exciting to be part of life-saving research. The benefits are great. If you don't like change, you will love working here.
cons: It is a VERY political environment

review_title: This is the best place to work on campus.
pros: Best job to have on a university campus because of flexible hours and decent pay.
cons: Some downsides to working here would be poor management and constantly changing policies.

review_title: A simple job to have while you're at school
pros:
Most of the employees at the UCLA are students which makes the work environment pretty relevant. 
You get a 20% discount and at an Employee appreciation day you get 33% off.
cons: This is a very simple and manageable job.

job_title: Clinical Care Partner in Santa Monica, CA
pros: The pay is nice, and the ratio of staff to patients is about normal, some days are harder than others, but usually not so bad.
cons: Not many downsides of working at UCLA besides the fact that their HR is horribly slow

job_title: Student Affairs Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It is rewarding to work with students and help them get a good education.
cons: Part-time hours are not enough to live on in Los Angeles

review_title: PhD get paid low income salaries
pros:
The University itself is great but this position that requires a PhD pays 1/2 of the salary one would get paid in the industry.

The position does come with great health benefits.
cons: Low wages especially for a position that requires a PhD.

review_title: They'll chew you up and spit you out.
job_title: Staff Research Associate in San Luis Obispo, CA
pros: Got to work in my field doing what I want to do
cons: Politics, crummy communication, too many bean counters, terrible bureaucratic mess, cold attitude from higher-ups.

pros:
Many opportunities to learn cutting edge technologies. 
Great atmosphere for innovation.
cons:
Political budgetary issues are taking a toll on morale.
As a public school it is difficult to compete with the private schools sometimes.
Tuition hikes.

pros: easy access to BART and location is good for most bay area residents
cons:
Too Corporate but without the benefit of the higher salary 
No value placed on employee development
Managers are hired with no supervisory experience

review_title: The Institution ok, my department where I worked was bad.
pros: Can learn a lot, work with all culture but you have to have good supervisor.
cons: I was very unlucky to have a bad supervisor that  cared for himself.

pros: Brilliant and caring people who are values driven to truly make a difference.
cons: Many old style managers who limit growth of the organization and employees.

pros: The fact that you work at UC Berkeley always makes people feel comfortable with the level of work that you're able to do.
cons: There is always budget cuts and you never know if you make it. It's causes PTSD

pros: Amazing higher education institution in California
cons: Concerns for post completion employment and not a great fit with faculty mentor

review_title: Rewarding and frustrating. Becoming more bureaucratic under the guise of efficiency.
pros: Ability to improve the University and hello broaden it's role.
cons: Too much favoritism, president, while starting our as an advocate is now a liability.

review_title: nice place to start with, but it's very hard to advance
pros:
great benefits, pleasant environment and good location
Most people are nice, but some mid management need training...no management/people skills
cons: not much advancement opp. and no reward for hard work

review_title: Excellent University with a variety of programs and opportunity, should increase connectivity.
pros: Good professors, Good programs, Good grading scale, alright job opportunities
cons: Could have a better post grad network, Need to hire more phds, Too Eurocentric

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Barbara, CA
pros:
-Worked around student's class schedule
-Opportunity to win Student Scholarship and earn money towards your ACCESS card
-Able to meet and work with other students
-Location is convenient to work between classes
cons:
-Managers often opposed each other
-Could only get work about 10 hours per week

review_title: Students apply now! They'll work with you!
pros: A job that accommodates the student's schedule! Not a very stress heavy job!
cons: It can be pretty boring, it does not have a substantial amount to offer in terms of experience.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: There are lots of great people to interact with here
cons: The political (historic and current) is a headache as well as local housing prices do not match well with salary.

pros: Worked with a great group of people. The supervisor I reported to is awesome; she gave me the room to figure things out but always gave me guidance when needed.
cons: Like most state agencies, it is hard to implement change when needed.

pros:
Excellent Pay
Excellent Benefits
Health 
Dental
Medical
Vision all excellent
100% tuition assistance (Depending on budget)
cons:
Power and Politics can get out of hand  - slows the production of the job down
People are promoted with no management skills - or emotional intelligence
Not all positions, only some.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Oakland, CA
pros: Opportunity to enhance the understanding of undergraduate students. Provide additional support for students that need extra help during office hours.
cons: The support from the head instructor can be lacking.

review_title: UC provides excellent environment to work in with amazing benefits.
pros: The environment is great.  Access to fantastic events and great benefits.
cons: Salaries aren't very competitive but it is made up through other ancillary items.

pros: Nice job , flexible, nice environment, Worked for 3 years for reaserch and developemnt and job is challenging and nice.
cons: OK compensation. Nice job , flexible, nice environment, Worked for 3 years for reaserch and developemnt and job is challenging and nice.

review_title: UC Merced is a great place to work
pros: UC Merced has amazing, hardworking employees. The sense of community is amazing.
cons: Due to the fact that the school is growing so quickly, employees are often bogged down with the workload of 2-3 employees.

job_title: Staff Research Associate I in Oslo
pros: Hiking spots very close if you are an outdoor person, Close to Bay Area
cons: Living is very Expensive, Tax deduction is too much, Little to no savings, Research Station at a Remote Location, Less Payscale, Less room for professional growth.

review_title: I learned some marketable skills but was discouraged with the slow pace.
pros: Stability. Friendly environment. Good benefit package. Relatively low-stress environment with cordial employees.
cons: Less motivated atmosphere than other places I've worked. There was a limited potential for advancement.
